dataset.title: Salvadora australis as an ecosystem engineer of sodic sites in the northern Kruger National Park

address.deliveryPoint: School of Animal Plant and Environmental Sciences, University of the Witwatesrand

abstract.para:
The Phugwane River in the northern Kruger National Park is flanked by bare sodic sites, of which Salvadora angustifolia Turril var. australis (Schweik.) Verdoon is the dominant woody species which grows in characteristic islands associated with undercanopy vegetation. Little vegetation grows between these islands, and this has led to the hypothesis that Salvadora australis is an ecosystem engineer of sodic sites, modulating soil properties which allows other vegetation to grow. A differential browsing response on these trees across sites also occurs. An investigation was undertaken to assess differences in physical and chemical properties of the soil under the canopy of trees and away from trees. Foliar chemistry, browsing response and tree physiognomy across sites was also assessed.
Soil under trees showed significantly decreased sodicity, concentrations of extractable sodium and magnesium and increased concentrations of calcium, C: N ratio and proportions of larger soil particles. Trees also increase in size and possibly age towards the riparian and upland boundaries of sites. Size was not correlated to a salinity gradient in the soil under trees or in the leaves of trees. This species has been shown to be a halophyte that accumulates sodium in the leaves at increasing concentrations with higher external salinity concentrations. It also performs selective portioning of ions as a tolerance strategy where old leaves have higher sodium concentrations and lower potassium concentrations than younger leaves. Browsing preference was not correlated with higher sodium concentrations of trees or leaves.
By inferring mechanisms of solute and water movement, this species has been shown to be an ecosystem engineer of the soil properties underneath it, which results in a better growing environment for other plants. This increases habitat heterogeneity across sites and species richness under canopies of trees. The increased biodiversity this species engineers has important managerial implications for Kruger National Park and demonstrates the importance of ecosystem engineers in semi-arid savanna ecosystems.

address.deliveryPoint: : Centre for Water in the Environment, School of Animal, Plant and Environmental Sciences, University of the Witwatersrand, Johannesburg.

section.title: Soil and Leaf Sample Collection
section.para: Ten trees were sampled at each site along a transect running the length of the bare patch perpendicular to the river to establish a gradient across the site to the river. The boundaries of the bare patch were characterised by vegetation and soil change from bare hard crusty soils to darker, more vegetated looser soils. The transect started from the riparian boundary of the bare area (characterised by occurrence of Colophospermum mopane and riparian vegetation) to the upland boundary (characterised by increasing frequency of C. mopane trees and decreasing frequency of S. australis.

Two soil cores were dug with an auger for each tree, with one at the base of the tree under the canopy and the other in bare soils, 1.5m from the edge of the canopy. Soil samples were taken every 20cm till one metre deep (0-20cm; 20-40cm; 40-60cm; 60-80cm; 80-100cm) with a total of 10 samples per tree. Soil was placed in brown paper bags, sifted through a 2mm sieve to mix the sample, and remove roots and gravel and dried at 65°C. The auger holes were back-filled with surrounding soil after the samples were removed.

Leaf samples were taken as a bulked sample from the whole canopy for each tree. This was then separated into young and old leaves, based on position on the stem and size of the leaf. The leaves were then dipped in deionized water to remove dust on the surface. Care was taken to avoid salt contamination by the use of latex gloves and minimal handling of leaves. The leaves were then dried at 55 °C until dry and easily broken.

Three additional trees of different size classes were sampled for texture analysis: 1 small, heavily browsed shrub (height =39cm), a medium shrub with a definite browse line (height =210cm), and a large tree that shows evidence of relatively little browsing (height =340cm). A trench was dug from the base of the tree to ~1.5m away from the edge of the canopy.

Soil samples were taken in horizons to a depth of 60cm, at intervals every 50cm along the trench for the small and medium trees and every 100cm for the large tree. Soil was investigated in the field for texture, colour, frequency of roots and occurrence of soil biota.

For these samples, texture analysis was performed in the laboratory by hydrometer method. This method uses sodium hexametamosphate to separate particles of different sizes from each other in a soil solution. The solution thoroughly mixed with an electrical stirrer and then left to settle for different periods when readings on the hydrometer are taken (40 seconds for %silt (20-50µm); 4 minutes for %silt (<2-20µm) and 2 hours for % clay (<2 µm)). % sand (50-2000µm) was calculated as the remaining percent. Calculations are corrected for temperature and moisture of the soil. pH and electroconductivity were also measured using hand-held field pH and E.C. meters in a 20g soil: 50ml deionised water solution (Anderson and Ingram, 1996).
Soil was sent to the Agricultural Research Council where it was analysed for total nitrogen by automated Kjedahl method, and carbon by modified Walkley-Black method.

section.title: Tree physiognomy
section.para: Tree physiognomy data were collected for each tree:
- canopy diameter at the longest length
- Browse height if actively browsed tree

Tree height was measured using a tape measure and/or ranging rod and taken from the base of the tree. Average stem circumference was determined from individual stem circumferences measured above the basal swelling of the tree. Browse height was taken as the height of very short trees that are browsed low, and from the ground to the bottom of a browse line on other trees. Trees that showed no browse line were given a score of 0.
The distance from each tree to the centre of the transect and sodic site was also estimated using a hand-held Garmin G.P.S. (with accuracy of ~1m).

section.title: Undercanopy Species Composition
section.para: Undercanopy woody and grass species were collected for each tree to asses species richness and composition. The species were pressed and identified in the Wits herbarium. Some specimens could not be conclusively identified as they were collected in the dry season and exhibited few taxonomic features.

section.title: Large Herbivore Exclosure Experiment
section.para: An exclosure experiment was set up in order to determine if herbivores are selecting for leaves with particular nutrient concentrations such as higher sodium on individual trees. Actively browsed trees from each site along the transect were selected with 2 near the outer edge of the site and one in the centre (n =9). Leaves were removed from branches that showed evidence of herbivory (leaves removed or ends of stems nipped) representing leaves that had not been selected by herbivores (pre-exclosure sample). The branches from which, these leaves had been removed, were marked with pink plastic ribbon. An exclosure was then constructed of 5mm green wire mesh, metal fence droppers and cable ties or coated flexible wire. For very small bushes, the entire bush was fenced off using the fencing droppers hammered into the ground (see figure 4 in the appendix). Individual browsed branches on larger trees were exclosed. Here the mesh was wrapped around the branch to bag the branch and tied using cable ties and wire (see figure 5 in the appendix). Where the wire bag was hard to see, white latex gloves were tied to it to prevent danger to any animals. Care was taken on all exclosures to ensure that the wire did not touch the growing shoots.

Nine weeks later I sampled leaves that had grown on the marked branches subsequent to the exclosure being erected (post-exclosure sample) as leaves that would have been browsed had herbivores not been prevented from feeding. Old leaves were also collected from within the exclosure to compare to the new post-exclosure leaves. Some exclosures were damaged by elephants and on one (44/5), the exclosure was removed and the tree appeared to have been subsequently browsed, therefore no sample was taken. Some branches also did not have sufficient leaf growth to sample for old leaves (68/5; 44/8). The exclosures were then dismantled and removed. Leaf samples were dried and milled for further analysis.

section.title: Soil and Leaf Chemistry Determination
section.para: Electrical conductivity and pH measurements were taken in the laboratory. The soil was sent to the Agricultural Research Council (ARC) in Pretoria for cation and SAR analysis. Soil samples from the first 8 trees from the upland side of site 83 were analysed for SAR as they showed high E.C. values in comparison with other trees. SAR was determined from a saturated paste extract using the Dumas method. The same soil samples from site 83 and samples from the exclosure trees from each site were analysed for selected extractable cations (Na+; Ca2+; Mg2+) and cation exchange capacity (CEC). Extractable cation analysis was by ammonium acetate extraction method (Anderson and Ingram, 1996), and determined by atomic absorption spectroscopy.

The dried leaf samples were milled to 0.5mm using a plant mill and sent to the Agricultural Research Council for selected nutrient analysis. The samples were analysed for Na+; Ca2+; Mg2+; K+; P using a mixed acid digestion and determined on an atomic absorption spectrophotometer.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Three bare patches wers chosen along the Phugwane river
Ten trees in each site were chosen.

Browse height was taken as the height of very short trees that are browsed low, and from the ground to the bottom of a browse line on other trees. Trees that showed no browse line were given a score of 0.
Average stem circumference was determined from individual stem circumferences measured above the basal swelling of the tree
